questions.text: People who care about my whole health (notice when something's off) are ...

answers.5: my inner circle — they notice and speak up
answers.3: a few — they notice some things
answers.1: none — no one's watching my health

questions.text: My attention to friends' overall wellbeing (noticing when they're not thriving) is ...

answers.4: consistent — I notice and say something
answers.5: deep — I'm watching for their whole wellbeing
answers.3: moderate — I pay attention to some

questions.text: People who would intervene if I made seriously unhealthy choices (and I'd let them) are ...

answers.5: my inner circle — full permission to intervene
answers.2: maybe one — but I might resist
answers.1: none — no one has that access

questions.text: Close relationships integrating body, soul, and spirit (not compartmentalized) is ...

answers.4: common — my close friends know the whole me
answers.5: normal — integrated friendship is the standard
answers.3: moderate — some integration in some relationships

questions.text: People who have walked with me through health crises (and I with them) are ...

answers.5: my trusted circle — we've proven faithful through hard times
answers.3: a few — we've been through some things

remediation.advice: Holistic fellowship means having people who see and care about all of you — not compartmentalized friendships that only touch one dimension. If no one in your life would notice or say something if you started declining, you don't have true fellowship. Build relationships with that depth of mutual attention.

scripture.text: A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.
